section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written by Marjorie Blain Parker Illustrated by Sophie Burrows
section-block.rac_book_summary: This rhyming story follows a boy as he counts down to the start of kindergarten and dreams of things he looks forward to. By counting sleeps, he knows how many days until the big day! Will it ever get here?

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 4: Dream Big

section-block.rac_body-text: Have children help you count to 10. Count up a few numbers at a time and pause, inviting children to say the next number in order. Repeat, counting backwards.
Have children count back from 10 as they sing “Ten Bottles of Milk.” They can act out taking one down and passing it around. Ask children to clap each time a number is said.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Kindergarten Countdown! by Marjorie Blain Parker and illustrated by Sophie Burrows.
You know Lala loves all sorts of books. She loves looking for ways to count in stories like this one!
There is a question that I want you to think about as we read:

section.rac_body-text: Focus on Counting: Encourage children to say the countdown aloud.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: We are going to read about a boy’s countdown to the start of kindergarten.
What do you think 10 more sleeps means? What time of day is it when you sleep?
Let’s count to 10 on our fingers!
Who do you think Buddy is? How many legs does Buddy have? Let’s count!
When you go somewhere new, do you bring a toy to play with?
Why is seven more sleeps the same as a week? How many days are there in a week?
The boy’s countdown reached seven! Let’s count down from seven to one: 7, 6, 5, 4, 3, 2, 1!
The tag is a name tag. What is the boy’s name? How many letters are in the name Tom?
What is Tom doing in this picture? Who knows the Pledge of Allegiance?
What number do you see on this page? What does 0 mean? What day is it now?
Let’s talk about the question: What is the boy counting?
section.rac_body-text: Have children Turn and Talk. Use Equity Sticks to ask several children to share their responses to the question.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: He is counting how many days until kindergarten starts.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short sentences about how long until kindergarten begins.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Is the boy counting sleeps or weeks?
What else could you count to tell how long until kindergarten begins?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Multilingual learners may find counting backward difficult. Not only do they have to remember the names of the numbers in a new language, but they have to remember them in reverse order! Display a number line or the digits 0–10 in the classroom and refer to them to help children visualize which number comes before and after.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 4: Dream Big

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Manage Change

rac_body-text.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Change happens all the time. The weather changes from cloudy to sunny. We change our clothes to get ready for school. One big change was when you started coming to preschool! Sometimes, change can make us nervous. But change is a part of growing up for everyone. What do you think about the change from preschool to kindergarten? Let’s talk about it.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we will reread some pages of Kindergarten Countdown! We will talk about how Tom acts during the changes in his life.
Clifford gets nervous when things change, too. But he also gets excited for new things! He loves reading books that help him think about what is coming next.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_body-text: Focus on Counting: Pause to have children point to the correct number card as you count objects on each page.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Who do you think Tom is going to wave goodbye to?
Without a fuss means without complaining. How do you think Tom feels about kindergarten if he leaves without a fuss? (MB)
Tom is going to find the door by himself! In kindergarten, he’s going to be more independent.
How many children are in the circle? Let’s count! Which number shows the right amount?
section.rac_body-text: Hold up numeral cards 7 and 9.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: We have Circle Time in preschool, too. When you go to kindergarten, will you know what to do? (MB)
How many swings are there? Let’s count! Which number shows the right amount?
section.rac_body-text: Hold up numeral cards 2 and 3.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Why is Tom too excited to sleep? Are you ever too excited to sleep before a big day? What do you do if you’re too excited to sleep? (MB)
How many spots are on Buddy’s back? Let’s count! Which number card shows the right amount?
section.rac_body-text: Hold up numeral cards 6 and 8.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Tom made new friends! Making new friends can make changes feel easier. What is one way you could make a friend? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Ask children to think about what they hope their kindergarten class will look like. What games do you hope to play in kindergarten? What might the teacher be like? What kind of books will you read? On a giant sheet of butcher paper, have children design their dream kindergarten classroom using a variety of materials.
Transcribe children’s speech as they ask questions about kindergarten.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Change causes uncertainty in everyone, especially young children. Help children adapt to change this week by noticing the changes they make each day: moving from one play center to another; switching activities; and transitioning from classroom to home. Discuss the upcoming move to kindergarten, and encourage questions. (Read & Patterson, 1980)

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 4: Dream Big

section-block.rac_body-text: Describe your morning using words that indicate the passing of time: Before school, I brushed my teeth. After that, I brushed my hair. Invite children to describe their mornings.
Play a game of Simon Says. As Simon, give children directions using before and after, such as: Simon says to touch your nose before touching your toes.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread Kindergarten Countdown! by Marjorie Blain Parker.
Lala loves reading stories about imaginary characters like Tom.
Today, we talked about things we do before school. As we read today, think about this question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What is one thing Tom does before starting kindergarten?

section.rac_body-text: Facilitate back-and-forth discussion with children to extend language.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Can someone point to the calendar? What information does a calendar tell us?
There are seven more sleeps before kindergarten! Has Tom started kindergarten yet?
He hasn’t! Tom is imagining what kindergarten will be like before he goes. That way, he can be ready for what happens next! (MB)
What do you imagine kindergarten will be like?
section.rac_body-text: Refer children to the imaginary kindergarten class they recently created on paper.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Tom is painting! What do you have to do before you paint? What do you think Tom will do with the painting after he’s done?
It’s finally the morning before Tom starts kindergarten! What does Tom do before he rides the bus? What does Tom do after?
Tom started kindergarten! What does Tom do before he reads? What does he do after?
Let’s talk about the question we thought about today. What is one thing Tom does before starting kindergarten?
section.rac_body-text: Have children Turn and Talk. Then use Equity Sticks to ask several children to share their responses to the question.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Tom imagines what kindergarten will be like.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you draw and write together about what they will do this summer.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What does Tom fill before he goes to kindergarten?
What is one thing you will do before kindergarten starts?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: At this stage, children are aware of past, present, and future. However, they are likely to have difficulty measuring time formally. Point to a clock or calendar to help children visualize the passage of time as you discuss hours and days. Will that happen in the future, or a time after now? We can use a calendar to measure how long that will be.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 4: Dream Big

section-block.rac_body-text: Talk with children about what they want to be when they “grow up.” Share what it means to be a teacher, and discuss other careers. What do you like to do?
Hold up numeral cards between 1 and 10, and have children jump, hop, spin, or clap that number of times. Encourage children to count aloud as they move.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read I Want To…. It is an informational poster that shows what you can do when you grow up.
I Want to… and Kindergarten Countdown! each focus on growing up. Let’s look for connections between the two!
We’re ready! What’s next?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the teacher text on the Big Chart, stopping to ask questions and count items on the chart.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How many laces are on the shoe? Let’s count!

Counting by twos means counting two at a time: 2, 4, 6, 8. You learned to count by ones this year: 1, 2, 3, 4! That’s a big change from not counting. What new things are you able to do now that you can count? (MB)
This chart rhymes, just like Kindergarten Countdown! Which words in these lines rhyme? What else rhymes with train?
How many cars are on the toy train in the picture? Let’s count!
You have been making art all year! What new things will you draw or paint in kindergarten?
When I’m all grown up means when I’m an adult. How long do you think it will be before you are all grown up? Am I all grown up?

section.rac_body-text: List careers children are interested in on a chart or board. Ask children to vote for one career to act out, and list the total votes for each career on the chart. Guide children to act out the winning career using any available props. Repeat with the next most popular careers.
Provide a writing prompt about what children want to be when they grow up. Give feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: To find a successful career, you first need to know what you are good at and like doing. Talking with children about what they want to be when they grow up, even at this young age, helps them start to think about those questions. Ask children to share jobs that their family members have to help them brainstorm a list of potential careers.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 4: Dream Big

section-block.rac_body-text: Ask children to share their favorite games, songs, and activities from this year. Think of a few favorites beforehand in order to gather any props or materials needed. Make a list of children’s choices on a chart or board. Read the options one by one, and have the class vote on which activity they want to do for this last Circle Time. Tally votes, and do the activities that get the most votes!
Play the PreK On My Way™ theme music one last time to celebrate the end of preschool. Invite children to dance and sing along however they wish!

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s read Kindergarten Countdown! one more time this week.
Lala wonders if this book tells a story or teaches information. Which is it?
We learned about changes and what to expect in kindergarten. When we read today, I want you to think about this question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What will you do to get ready for kindergarten?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread the book one more time together. This time, we’ll act out parts of the story!
Tom is going to wear new clothes to kindergarten! Do you think you will use anything new on the first day of kindergarten? (MB)
Let’s pretend to put new pencils in our bags for kindergarten!
Tom is also going to bring his toy and a snack to kindergarten with him. What do you want to bring to kindergarten from home? (MB)
Let’s pretend to put that special item from home into our bags.
There is a number chart on the wall! Who can come up and point to the number three? Who can point to the number six?
Tom is saying the Pledge of Allegiance! You will say the Pledge in kindergarten, too!
Let’s all practice saying it together.
How many red stripes can you see on this flag? Let’s count!
How many jump ropes do you see on this page? Let’s count!
Pretend to use a jump rope!
Tom made new friends! You’ll meet friends in kindergarten, too.
Some of your new friends might speak languages other than English. Let’s practice saying hello in languages we know!
section.rac_body-text: Some examples: hola (Spanish); bonjour (French); ni hao (Chinese).

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What will you do to get ready for kindergarten?
section.rac_body-text: Give children time to Turn and Talk. Then ask several children to share with the group.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: I will pack a toy or snack.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write a story about what they will do on the first morning of kindergarten.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What could you practice before you start kindergarten?
Before starting kindergarten, I will practice c___ (counting).
Before starting kindergarten, I will practice counting.
Do you have other questions about getting ready for kindergarten?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: It’s the last day of preschool! Share with children how proud you are of them and how proud they should be of themselves. Ask children for any remaining questions they have about kindergarten, and share anything you know about the kindergarten classes they will join. If possible, schedule a visit before the end of the year.
